head.title: Horse of a Different Color, Literally

hedline.hl1: Horse of a Different Color, Literally

abstract.p: Article on Patchen Beauty, all-white race horse, preparing for her maiden race (S)

block.p: She is untested as a race horse and comes from a line of also-rans, but Patchen Beauty's place in history is secure.

The 2-year-old filly's fame was guaranteed at birth, when she literally appeared as a horse of a different color. Patchen Beauty is pure white, making her only the ninth white thoroughbred registered with the Jockey Club.
She is untested as a race horse and comes from a line of also-rans, but Patchen Beauty's place in history is secure.

The 2-year-old filly's fame was guaranteed at birth, when she literally appeared as a horse of a different color. Patchen Beauty is pure white, making her only the ninth white thoroughbred registered with the Jockey Club.

''I think she's a celebrity, but she's kept her head,'' her owner, Warren Rosenthal, said. ''She knows she gets a lot of attention. She even gets attention from the other horses. They look at her a little bit funny, too.''
Rosenthal said his young prize is a ''sweet-tempered horse.''
''Of course, she's been spoiled since she was born,'' he said. ''So she's very calm and easy to handle and enjoys being patted.''
The filly is stabled at Churchill Downs' off-track barns in Louisville, Ky., and is being prepared for her maiden race at the fall meet.
It was not purely accidental that Patchen Beauty was born pure white at Rosenthal's Patchen Wilkes Farm in Lexington, Ky. Her mother and great-grandmother were white. Her sire, Hatchet Man, was gray.
Her great-grandmother, White Beauty, became the first white thoroughbred registered with the Jockey Club. Rosenthal did not own the white matriarch but owns the filly's mother, Precious Beauty.
Rosenthal hopes that Patchen Beauty does not emulate her mother and great-grandmother as a runner. White Beauty won just once, and Rosenthal said that was ''by accident.''
White Beauty's only victory came on a cold, wet fall day when attendance was sparse at Keeneland in Lexington, so there was little crowd noise to distract her.
Yonkers Raceway, citing a lack of money, has canceled the Clare Pace and the William Haughton Memorial Pace, the track's general manager, Bob Galteria, said yesterday.
The $35,000 Clare was scheduled for Saturday, and the $100,000 Haughton Memorial was to be raced on Nov. 7.
Earlier this year, Yonkers canceled the George Morton Levy Pace and the Cane Pace.
